qas.question: Who argued against works where the author listens to input from others?
Who wanted to determine why an author made changes to a work?
Does Greg believe a later work can be substituted for a earlier one?

answers.text: a later reading "is one that the author can reasonably be supposed to have substituted for the former

qas.question: Who argued for works where the author listens to input from others?
Who didn't want to determine why an author made changes to a work?
Who believes an earlier work can be substituted for a later one?
Constrained authorial intention was whose idea?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Bowers and <b5_0><b7_0>Tanselle<b7_0/><b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> argue for rejecting textual variants that an author inserted at the suggestion of others. Bowers said that his edition of Stephen Crane's first novel, Maggie, presented "the author's final and uninfluenced artistic intentions." In his writings, <a1_0>Tanselle<a1_0/> refers to "<a3_0>unconstrained authorial intention<a3_0/>" or "an author's uninfluenced intentions." This marks a departure from <b6_0>Greg<b6_0/>, who had merely suggested that the editor inquire whether <a2_0>a later reading "is one that the author can reasonably be supposed to have substituted for the former<a2_0/>", not implying any further inquiry as to why the author had made the change.
